page.title: Let’s Review the Principles
page.contents:
• Critical thinking can and should be practiced at all levels of instruction.
  • Critical thinking can and should be added as a layer to any curriculum.

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT4_0310.mp3

Audio transcript


Before you complete a final application activity, let’s review some key ideas from Unit 4. Critical thinking can and should be practiced at all levels of instruction. This can be done by adding a layer of critical thinking to existing activities, lessons, and curricula. Teachers can create lessons with multiple possible answers or that require a level of analysis. They can use graphic organizers to show the relationship between ideas. They should be asking questions that go beyond recall. They can use the Depth of Knowledge wheel as they are planning instruction. What can you do to support these efforts?

In the next section, we’ll explore how to access the Employability Skills Framework and the Minnesota Transitions Integration Framework to inform lesson and curriculum development. We’ll consider study circles and peer mentoring as vehicles for helping teachers promote higher levels of critical thinking in their lessons with adult ELLs.

page.title: Visit the Employability Skills Framework
page.contents:
• Overview of employability skills
  • Assessment checklists
  • Lesson planning checklists
  • Resources

The Employability Skills Framework is a one-stop resource for information and tools to inform the instruction and assessment of employability skills.

Visit the section on Critical Thinking.

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT4_0320.mp3

Audio transcript


Individuals require many skills to be college and career ready, including academic knowledge, technical expertise, and a set of general, cross-cutting abilities called employability skills. The Employability Skills Framework is a one-stop resource for information and tools to inform the instruction and assessment of employability skills. The site contains an overview of employability skills, assessment and lesson planning checklists, as well as links to a wide variety or resources. It contains a section on critical thinking with a particular focus on decision making and creative problem solving. Take some time now to visit the site and look specifically at what is offered for working on critical thinking appropriate to your setting. Notice that the site includes information related to other topics in the module and in the LINCS ESL Pro Project, for example contextualized career pathways instruction.

page.title: Engage in Critical Conversations
page.contents:
• Provide a lesson analysis template
  • Provide opportunities for peer observation
  • Create reading circles using resources from this module
  • Visit Minnesota's ACES project and Transitions Integration Framework
  • Introduce teachers to the Employability Skills Framework

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT4_0330.mp3

Audio transcript


The most important thing to remember is that for teacher change and development to happen, teachers need time work together in meaningful ways. Here are some ways that you can build reflection on critical thinking, as well as all the topics covered in this module, among instructors in your program. During meeting times, provide the lesson analysis template linked to here and have teams review and discuss lessons they teach. What enhancements could they make to their lessons? What are doing well and what are some missed opportunities for developing critical thinking?

Another option is a more structured peer-mentoring project. The process linked to here has been used very successfully in Minnesota. It takes commitment on your part to give release time and space for implementation of and reflection on practice.

Be sure to provide time and space for study circles. The resource section of this unit and module provides a multitude of readings and website that teachers can explore, study on report on in small groups.

One final idea is to have teachers visit Minnesota’s Academic, Career and Employability Skills (ACES) project and the Transitions Integration Framework and the Employability Skills Framework. Although developed for adult education, there are a multitude of ideas and applications for teachers of adult ELLs. There are also webinars and sample lesson plans for teachers.
